title: Rugby World Cup 2019: Fiji star Sam Matavesi pleads for return of stolen medal, jerseys and more
text:
Fiji forward Sam Matavesi has called on the public to help him recover a series of prized possessions after they were stolen from his car in London.

The 27-year-old has now returned to England after his side's pool stage exit from the tournament in Japan but has devastatingly had shirts, medals and caps taken from him.

The hooker, who plays for Championship side Cornish Pirates, discovered the items had been taken from his car in London after he returned from Japan. He also lost his boots and training kit in the robbery.

Fiji forward Sam Matavesi has called on the public to help him recover some stolen items

The hooker (third from left) discovered the items had been taken from his car in London

MATAVESI FACTFILE Age: 27 Position: Hooker Height: 5 ft 11 in Weight: 229 lb Club career so far: 2010-15 - Plymouth 2015- Cornish Pirates 2019 - Toulouse (loan) International career so far: 12 caps 8 starts 3 tries stats from ESPN Scrum

Matavesi has taken social media to ask the public for help, writing a desperate plea for any assistance on Facebook.

'After arriving from Japan I stayed the evening in London,' he said.

'We stayed in Shoreditch and parked the car overnight at NCP Finsbury Square car park. When we returned the following day our car had been burgled and my World Cup kit bags had been stolen from it.

'The bags contained three Fiji World Cup jerseys, plus other signed Fiji World Cup shirts, my World Cup cap and presentation medal, rugby kit, boots, trainers, gym shoes and other personal memorabilia.

'Could you please share this and look out for any shirts/kit/boots etc that come up online, or if you hear or see anything around the area.

'Thanks in advance, Sam.'

Matavesi has taken social media to ask the public for help, writing a desperate Facebook plea

Matavesi played in every match for Fiji during the World Cup, including the 29-17 defeat by Wales. He started three of the four group games, coming off the bench in the other.

The Fijians failed to make it through to the quarter-finals after finishing third in Pool D.

They were also beaten by Australia and Uruguay but did manage to secure a 35-point win over Georgia.
